item.description:
Summer Carillon Concert At Yale  

 

Every summer, the Guild organizes a Summer Concert Series where we invite carillonneurs from around the world and the United States to come to Yale to perform. 

All concerts begin at 7:00 pm and last approximately one hour. They are free and open to the public. Seating is not provided, but audience members are encouraged to bring blankets and lawn chairs to the listening area. Listening space is available in the Branford College Courtyard beginning at 6.30 pm and is accessible from Elm St. and High St. In the event of rain or otherwise poor weather, indoor listening space will be available.

There are also students who will be on campus, and we ask that concertgoers be sensitive to these residents.

What is a carillon?

A carillon is a musical instrument composed of at least 23 bells, tuned in chromatic sequence. It is played from a console that resembles a simple organ, with batons (for the hands) and pedals (for the feet). These keys move the clappers (metal ball) that strike and sound the bells, which remain stationary. This set-up allows the carillonneur to play with great dynamic expression.

Quick Facts

  • Harkness Tower: 216 feet, 284 steps to the roof
  • The Carillon: 54 bells, pitched in B
  • Total Weight: 43 tons
  • Age of Bells: 10 bells were cast in 1921, the remainder in 1964
  • Lowest bell: F♯ concert pitch, 13,400 pounds
  • Highest bell: B♮concert pitch, 26 pounds
  • The Guild: Founded in 1949 by Elliot H. Kone BR '49, renamed in 1964; 26 members maximum

    You can enter the courtyard on High Street between Chapel and Elm Streets.  From Chapel, take a right onto High (one way street). Street parking is free after 7:00.  There is also a garage on York Street and Chapel Street.
  • We can have frozen yogurt at Froyo World at 46 High Street after the concert.
item.how_to_find_us: Will fly the bw scarf with piano keys
item.name: Summer Carillon Concert At Yale
